Television in the summer used to be a wasteland replete with reruns and lackluster programming. However, now there are two outstanding new series on television, and I have been following both devotedly for the past week. Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? Like when you're sitting in math class, bored to the marrow, and you ponder what precisely happens in your brain that allows you to grasp math? You become aware that you exist, that you are in a math class, and you wonder why. Then it dawns on you how astonishing existence is. Last night in class, we discussed that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World," by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter deals with "implacement" and the second with "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey makes the argument that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is attempting to argue that situating place at the center of culture yields a more grounded community. (That is a very rough summary, a disclaimer in case my professor or any classmates happen to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly captivated me.

Fall 1974: I was attempting for what felt like the thirteenth time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high-school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a "math person." I detest math. I am math-phobic. You get the picture. So, as I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my study and just as I was discovering a little glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs—an uninvited practical joker.

GOP Gets Scolded on Recruitment: Naturalization Ceremonies in Jacksonville Are to Be Relocated After Complaints That GOP Activists Registered New Citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed as usual, with a throng of nearly 200 individuals departing as new Americans. Just before the new citizens exited the June 29 event, an immigration official supervising the swearing-in encouraged them to visit a voter registration table -- a sight not unusual at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was atypical: those distributing forms were Republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been pre-checked to enlist all of the new voters into the GOP. This scenario raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who attended to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

As a non-American blogger, I've been somewhat hesitant to engage in some of these discussions, especially those concerning flags, but since I initiated the topic (the subject, not the act of flag-burning), I suppose I'd better contribute my thoughts. Firstly, I believe that the concept of legislating against flag-burning is utterly absurd. The moment you begin to ascribe to a symbol—any symbol—that level of inflexible reverence and protection, you have taken a minor yet significant step toward totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently mercurial—they don't intrinsically represent anything; it's the meaning they're perceived to convey or are assigned that's significant.

It places the ball in the goal, or it faces the hose again. Absolutely astonishing—I have nothing but praise for this game as it has surpassed my expectations and will likely surpass yours as well. Fluid movement, bug/crash-free, abundant story/content to engage you, and daily options such as various practices, events (such as sponsorships), and even games. Magic fans, beware... Wizards fears making a decent digital game. At its heart, Magic: The Gathering is a social game—a game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies), laughing, talking smack, and playing game-winning bombs. Wizards of the Coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, and gold is crucial. Gold is so crucial that they have implemented a daily cap, which is understandable, considering gold unlocks everything in-game. But brace yourself for a lengthy and tedious 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, with whom you can’t even communicate. If you opt to play for free, it will take you approximately 4 hours a day for over a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.

Being the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negative aspects first. I generally dislike prequels because they represent a regression in the storyline rather than advancement (a problem inherent to every prequel). Granted, they can expand on the narrative. The combat feels disjointed and lacks the precision that Arkham City achieved. As of writing this review (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from ever being completed (the main story is not affected). Some gadgets are assigned to an impractical hotkey, requiring your hand to traverse the entire keyboard to access it. It might seem trivial, but during combat, it could disrupt your combo.

They effectively improved Shadow Warrior (2013); that is, the boss fights are remarkable, weapons are satisfying (perhaps not quite on par with D44M's, but still substantial), and enemies are not overly resilient (provided you are adept with elemental attributes and upgrade mechanics). The upgrade system is excellently balanced, and once you become acquainted with it, it's not overly cumbersome. The restrictions on ammunition and elemental attributes subtly encourage the utilization of various weapons. Numerous distinctive (a key term here when contrasting SW2 with the repetitive Borderlands' RNG weapon system) weapons remain useful throughout most of the game. The music is outstanding, particularly the main theme, and of course, Stan Bush's contributions.

So many things were made wrong. I don't even know how to begin this review. This all refers to my career. My player is an outside scorer, PG, 1.71m, has maxed-out stats, and has already acquired all necessary perks. Okay, now tell me, why does the shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can't someone who is 1.74m become as proficient in shooting as someone who is 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, created my first player with this height, and then realized I cannot achieve a skill higher than 89. Why? That's outright discrimination! And why doesn't the game inform me of this before I create a character, or even when I reach the skill cap after weeks of playing?!

I believe this Assassin's Creed has perfected the mechanics across the board (ship combat, navigation, fishing, parkour, etc.). I found myself much more invested in this protagonist as well. The narrative begins quite abruptly but significantly improves as you continue playing (I think this is typical for every AC game, in my opinion). Edward was a truly intriguing character, as were all the supporting cast. I felt that the collectibles genuinely added value in this AC title, unlike what I experienced with any of the prior entries, possibly because they seemed more integral to the game. They certainly weren't mandatory, but collecting them was enjoyable and the rewards were well balanced.

While I personally cannot endorse this game, it wasn't abysmal. The gunplay is acceptable, provided you have the funds to acquire gun components, which constitutes my primary critique of this game: it's predicated on pay-to-win. If I could overlook that aspect, the game would be quite enjoyable, as the hardsuit is entertaining to operate, and HRV is an innovative concept. I'd prefer this game to any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction scheme is unpalatable for me. If you are comfortable with this model, then by all means, enjoy yourself. However, if you're like me and oppose pay-to-win mechanics, just let this one pass; it's not our cup of tea.

While not flawless, the game has been immensely enjoyable. The save system and potential for sudden death contribute to some frustration. I'm on my initial playthrough, and I lost my main character at about the 10th hour of roughly 20. I would have appreciated the option to reload a save at that juncture. I've since utilized a third-party mod/save tool to prevent devastating losses. Additionally, the aiming reticle is somewhat diminutive, and the zoom capability is inadequate. Despite these issues, it has been a thrill. I am not typically fond of zombie genres, but the blend of strategy, missions, first-person shooter/beat 'em up is outstanding. I play as frequently as my schedule permits... Just one more mission, just one more supply run – or I'm fleeing to safety before closing the game.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every single other wargame (European Escalation, and ALB), I must say this one fits well. The variety of units is impressive. I'm not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a tremendous amount!!! The graphics are simply stunning, the sounds are exceptional, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well – no, I am not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to master it. Do not get frustrated; you will lose many units. Just ensure that you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank capabilities.

I harbored a negative bias toward this game before I played it. Wasn't even certain about purchasing it. I don't know, the whole concept of a portal gun and portals seemed odd to me even though I enjoy science fiction. Boy, was I mistaken. The humor and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. Truly outstanding. It's not cheesy (okay, it's occasionally cheesy). And the various story characters each have their unique sense of humor. These distinct characters indeed possess unique personalities. As for the level design; it's simply superb. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to, if I can find the time. I would never have played it if I hadn't experienced the sequel.

OK, let's start with the pros(+) and cons(-), then my thoughts on this game. Pros:
+ some of the best characters
+ engaging story
+ a wealth of content
+ customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you prefer)
+ you can foster relationships with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest) Cons:
- mediocre graphics (though I don't think graphics are all that important)
- awkward love scenes
- invisible barriers
- there's one mission, in my opinion, that was dull, but everyone has different tastes Neutral:
± This isn't really bad or good, but for those who care, your protagonist that you create can't speak. Now for my thoughts: I adore this game. It's probably one of the best RPGs or games in general that I have ever played. So, if you're an RPG fan, you probably already own this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallett just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is present. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is impeccable, and very much Generation One. But aside from that, it’s actually a very entertaining game. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well-executed. Transforming mid-fight is often essential, and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon’s excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another distinction is the substantial focus on melee combat, though certain enemies (e.g., Seekers) necessitate a switch to a ranged blaster.

So I downloaded the game and played it for a short time, but it was quite ordinary. I devoted more time to attempting to log in than to actually engaging with the game. There's a glitch where it reports that there was an update to the terms of service or something similar, and every time you clicked 'accept', it would just reappear. You have to restart the client for it to function properly. Although it's not terribly inconvenient, why must I link my Steam and GFACE accounts? They claim it’s for DLC, but why is that necessary? Additionally, it’s irreversible, so now I'm aware that a company I'm indifferent about has access to my Steam information. As for the game itself, it’s mediocre. It’s easily identifiable as a COD imitator, yet they managed to deteriorate the gunplay... How is that even feasible?

4K at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and Neptune gear included—what’s not to adore? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo. An excellent port and a great entry point for newcomers to the series. Just keep in mind there is a lot of (skippable) dialogue. I would usually suggest using a gamepad, but I personally encountered no issues with a keyboard/mouse setup; both are completely rebindable. The price is about right, and I wouldn't have regretted a purchase. More than half the DLC is included for free, which offers plenty of content. I recommend this game to all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don’t mind lengthy breaks between action sequences. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLSfLVijaUPSzEZ9Af395MVNk63XnHSj1_

I encountered no performance issues even upon release, and with all the updates, it now plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, this is an outstanding and entertaining game, truly, even though the format can be slightly irritating (where the free-roam city area restocks with new adversaries each time you advance the story). I particularly relished the 'dual play' sequences (where you can control Batman and an additional character), and the option to utilize the controller for most parts of the game while reserving the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat sequences was highly appreciated. Navigating your Batmobile around the free-roaming city, especially when pursuing the APC commanders, becomes notably pleasurable once you learn how to use the brakes to drift around corners (and mastering this skill makes driving through the city thoroughly enjoyable!).

An outstanding first-person shooter - that's the essence. Its visuals and audio are top-notch, and the gameplay is excellent - featuring solid shooting mechanics, an engaging story, memorable characters, impeccable voice acting, and a thrilling soundtrack. It's not suitable for the sensitive, however - some of those cutscenes were quite intense and graphic. Yet when a game is so exceptional, its imperfections are more noticeable, and here they are as I perceived them: - No SLI support - perplexing. I had to shelved the game until I updated my card, as it performed too sluggishly on my outdated dual GPU GTX 590. Ensure you possess a reasonably powerful single GPU card.
- Frustratingly minor obstacles are frequently insurmountable.

English is not my native language; I am Dutch. Therefore, please overlook any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this outstanding game. I will organize this review into several categories: 
- graphics 
- controls 
- sound 
- gameplay 
- replayability  - Graphics: The game adopts a comic book style. The visuals are very polished: no unnecessary details. The color schemes are appealing and harmonize perfectly with the game. You can see from the hours I’ve put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I hoped a search game from CoD would be. However, don’t purchase this game expecting it to be like CoD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It’s in a class of its own and should be regarded accordingly. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve heard new players grumble and lament about being killed swiftly. Oh, heaven forbid you get shot in the face and actually die. It's not as if such incidents occur in real life or anything. Edit: Okay, I’ve been playing this game for a while now. Invested quite a bit of money in it. One of the best multiplayer games out there. A great option to play when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and am overwhelmed with laughter from this game. Incredibly funny. The gameplay is robust, the art design captivating, the music is of impressively high quality and fitting, the story and world engaging, and the puzzles are entertaining. However, the pinnacle of this game, beyond all else, is the humor. If you've played any RPG since the inception of video game RPGs, you will chuckle at the myriad jokes, parodies, and references. If you've never dabbled in RPGs before, you will still find enjoyment in the game's wit. Those familiar with Final Fantasy VII or X will find this title indispensable; without revealing too much... After two hours, I had to pause to give my cheeks a respite from the incessant laughing and smiling. What a pleasure it has been thus far.

I'm really sorry; I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I truly didn't enjoy this game. The description seemed right up my alley, but the execution has done nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still simply didn't find the gameplay itself fun. It also completely lacks a pause button, or if it does have one, I never discovered it. Considering that many sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel that this game is a lot more cutscene than gameplay, and I end up just sitting around, tapping my fingers a lot.

This game... Whew, where to even start? It was absolutely beautiful, from the story to the graphics; I was captivated. The narrative wasn't just any story; it made me feel as if I were the protagonist, eager to discover what came next in the tale my character was unfolding. The gameplay was exceptional, and the experience taught me a lot about myself—mainly my newfound fear of heights, which never concerned me until the ice caverns. My gut churned the entire time, but I persevered for Uncle Fred! If you guys produced a DLC or a sequel, I would be the first to purchase it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to all who were involved in creating this; you crafted a truly exquisite game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game in which you develop your civilization toward a specific goal, or 'victory'. In previous games, you were situated on Earth's historical timeline,  progressing through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and the Modern Age; however, in this installment, you are projected into the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K introduced a fresh perspective and incorporated novel mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. What I found less enjoyable was that, at times, these new features made the game somewhat overwhelming. An aspect I believe could be enhanced is the inclusion of additional artwork within the game, such as the environments you encounter when communicating with another leader.

Fantastic game! Abundant replay value and incredibly entertaining zombie survival experience! Definitely in my top 5 list of zombie games ever played. Edit: After investing 60+ hours, I can sincerely affirm this is among the finest and more 'authentic' zombie games out there. It's intricately crafted as a survival horror where you must conserve your ammunition, attend to your wounds when you're bleeding, take medication when you're infected, etc. Moreover, the zombies appear very natural and are impressively animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend teaming up with one or two friends for an enhanced experience, but the community is exceedingly welcoming, and you can typically befriend and communicate with other players in the chat or via voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's regrettable that I cannot wholeheartedly recommend or enjoy this game; despite the limited time I've spent with it, I'm certain I would be engrossed if it weren't for the following two major issues. Firstly, the absence of Australian servers—a single red bar leaves you substantially disadvantaged and results in intolerable lag. Keep in mind, I played through the offline training mode, and even there I experienced stutters and lag (how is that even possible?). Combined with the high ping, it utterly ruins the experience. Secondly, the visuals are extremely problematic—menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game elements all artifact excessively. I've never encountered such an issue with this graphics card and suspected it might be a conflict with my overclocking. Reverting the GPU to its factory settings proved fruitless; disappointingly, it had no impact.

Very late last night, I finished this. The story is not particularly deep or captivating, but what distinguishes it is the storytelling. The atmosphere is richly detailed, and the multitude of collectibles excellently enhances it. I learned much about the world of Batman, so it was somewhat disappointing that there were so few bosses in the game. Oh well, there are sufficient future games to address that. The combat strikes the right balance in terms of challenge, although it leans more towards the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't particularly rewarding. It's the gadgets that you upgrade and acquire during the campaign which contribute to engaging new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously inaccessible areas provides a gratifying sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a superlative experience, and it was one of the finest of my life at that. Think Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Ha! It pales in comparison to 'To the Moon'! Never before have I felt so profoundly moved yet fulfilled by something entirely fictional. This masterpiece epitomizes the zenith of storytelling, in my view, and the soundtrack is a delightfully enchanting and faultless complement. Yes, the controls are somewhat cumbersome and the gameplay is not a highlight, but the narrative is so extraordinary that it didn't bother me in the slightest. Moreover, the wit of the game is excellent as well and it certainly does not detract from the esteemed nature of the story... And the 'Doctor Who' references are plentiful.

Bastion is a superbly brilliant game, with an exceptionally engaging storyline. Set after some catastrophic event, you begin to rebuild on the bastion. There is quite a variety in gameplay, with options for what to construct to gain an advantage, which weapons to wield, and which power-ups to equip on those weapons, as well as which tonics to consume for additional benefits. The art style and music in the game are outstanding; everything appears immensely vibrant at times—who says the apocalypse has to be dreary? Best of all, the game features dynamic narration that responds to your actions. So, if you pick up a weapon and then exchange it for another in the armory, the narrator will comment on your selection of the new weapon.

I had originally purchased this game during its early development when the exclusive currency was spacebucks, and there was no 'tech tree'. That was when the game excelled. All weapons at that time were supremely powerful, resulting in no issues of imbalance; everyone had the capability to eliminate any opponent at any moment. Additionally, the game formerly granted unlimited weapon slots and five loadouts. You would assume that for a game boasting 'bajillions of guns', they would provide more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring payment for expansion. At one juncture, I possessed approximately three pages' worth of weapons and was contemplating new concepts for more, because, personally, that's where I derived enjoyment.

This game was a surprising gem. One often encounters rave reviews of certain products that can sometimes be misleading. In this instance, the reviews accurately reflect the entertainment value of this neat little game. It is an unusual blend of a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with panache. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically appreciate in other MOBA games. While I had anticipated this preference to persist, I decided to try playing as a melee tank regardless. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and subsequently experimented with more characters as they became available through gameplay. The art style and interface are peculiarly captivating. Consequently, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper derived from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat encounter, and they’ve optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counterattack. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced numerous changes to the series, especially for the series' protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series might be dismayed by the alterations to their cherished character, it's undeniably for the better, and this new game by Ninja Theory corroborates that. DmC serves as an ideal entry point for newcomers to immerse themselves in the series. It reveals the beginnings of an arrogant and cynical Dante, charting his transformation from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout the game, a coherent narrative arc for the refreshed Dante is woven, rendering him an engrossing character to follow. The story portrays Dante as he becomes acquainted with the corrupt world he had previously opted to disregard.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is enchanting. It boasts meticulous detail, exuding a bundle of joy, clever puns, amusing dogs, and secrets. It strikes a serious tone when necessary, yet it revels in humorous moments. The character design is impeccable, featuring a variety of characters with distinct personalities and secrets to uncover. It stands out from other RPGs because it allows you to progress without the need to vanquish anyone, which is a novel concept in RPGs. Drawing extensive inspiration from EarthBound, one of the finest RPGs I have encountered, you can discern its potential for greatness. It possesses what is arguably the best soundtrack I've listened to in a long time.

I am recommending this solely because it is complimentary, and it might provide a more 'enthralling' experience for others. Regarding my experience, the 'game' was ineffectual for me. A significant portion of the narrative relies on shock value. I was neither shocked nor emotionally stirred by it in the slightest. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or it may have been too straightforward to elicit a response from me. As for the remaining portion of the game, it attempts to illustrate (metaphorically) a person's mental deterioration. It addresses obsession, hallucinations, depression, and several other issues. Conceptually, it is an intriguing idea. However, the 'game' took me merely 10 minutes to complete, and that was with reading and absorbing every scrap of information I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game; it presents you with a concept and then steps back. It is a remarkable way to test your mind while still being entertaining. Though this game isn't as rich in narrative, it did inspire one of the most distinguished and popular games of 2011. I still play this game to defeat boredom, and I cherish the opportunity to revisit what laid the foundation for a legend and what has become a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite straightforward to describe. You utilize portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: one that you press directly, and another that requires a cube for activation.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally encountered only twice: one minor and the other quite vexing) — note: both issues are resolved now, with one fix boosting my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120 — and are seeking a space exploration game, I can unreservedly recommend this one. Since many of these reviews focus on specifications, I'll share mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX480 (~200€), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~150€), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€). The total of approximately 650€ certainly falls within the mid-range category; though it's fair to say, this setup is fairly recent. Almost consistent 60+ FPS on high settings with Vsync enabled, I genuinely can't fathom why 90% of the commenters claim they're using an overpowered rig yet only achieve 20FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yes, it has been that long since an RTS game of such caliber was released. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes remarkably close to reaching the heights of my all-time favorite RTS game. Combine this with a massive Risk-like grand strategy mode, and there, it hits the mark. I try (read: endeavor not to be) to avoid being overly biased due to the fact that this game enables you to transform into a dragon, assisting your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, movement, and spawning simultaneously. Honestly, I do appreciate the intricate RTS games available nowadays, such as Civ V and others. Nevertheless, such games tend to incorporate complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into a single convoluted game mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are impressive for a retro title, and the music is delightful; together, they forge truly exquisite and impactful moments. The script spans the gamut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all simultaneously, and achieves this while subverting RPG tropes. And all of this without discussing the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write extensive essays about it. But instead, I'll simply say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven spare hours between now and your demise, play this game.

If you enjoyed The Witcher 1 and 2, The Witcher 3 is a must-have. Normally, I would rate this game a perfect 10/10, but unfortunately, after patch 1.03, the game evolved into a buggy mess with random crashes, so remember to save your progress frequently. When I played versions 1.00 through 1.03, my game never crashed, and I didn’t encounter any bugs. I’ve also noticed that after the 1.03 patch, the draw distance has occasionally been poor, with objects starting to render when you’re extremely close, sometimes even with characters. However, if we overlook these bugs, crashes, and draw distance issues, this is an outstanding game. The developers put tremendous effort into the quests, some of which are very emotional and profound. There are countless side quests, and the fact that your decisions significantly impact the game. I have played for over 50 hours now and am still engaged.

I have only had this game for a few months, but in that brief period, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, which is evident in the various discussion forums and developer diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I am still attempting to master; however, this depth of strategy affords you a multitude of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. The game, in my estimation, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself engrossed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough is unfolding.

Warframe is an entertaining game for the initial hours of play. After those enjoyable moments, you'll begin to notice that what remains is redundancy in its combat, adversaries, and gameplay. The primary highlight for the game is the developers' dedication, evidenced by their consistent updates, which usually introduce a substantial amount of content, including comprehensive revisions to some game systems, new Warframes, and additional adjustments/features. It's a suitable game for casual play. However, I doubt it will captivate your interest for more than a few months unless you particularly enjoy the grind. The advantage is that the game is free, so I would suggest giving it a try. If you're seeking a temporary diversion, give it a shot.

This game is exceedingly dull. I purchased it believing it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy,' a celebrated and enjoyable PS2 game. Regrettably, it falls short of expectations. In this game, you venture forth, engulfing increasingly larger objects to expand in size and assimilate larger entities. However, the gameplay lacks fluidity, the levels are uninspired, and the content resembles a surreal horror tableau. I do not refer to an amusement but rather to one that induces melancholy and prompts one to contemplate the meaning of existence. Every so-called 'living' being in this game, from diminutive pets to humans, leads me to speculate whether the creators harbored a fascination with taxidermy.

All right. Let me explain a few things. As a person very interested in politics, I was quite intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh, wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds exciting!" Well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side: Republican or Democrat; there is no Independent or third-party option. Somewhat disappointed, but still hopeful, I carried on to see what I could do. I will give the game credit; the character customization, although limited, is somewhat enjoyable to tinker with. It's the only time it's an option to wear a hat or not in a campaign. Literally.

The story in Fallout 3 was superior. Settlements disrupt the narrative to the extent that you'll resent having to manage them rather than engaging with the plot. Certain keys are rigidly mapped and cannot be reconfigured. The game is rife with bugs. My Pip-Boy vanished permanently at one stage, necessitating a delve into console commands to retrieve it. You aren't required to earn the power armor; it's essentially handed to you from the onset of the game, and fusion cores are abundantly available in traders' shops. The significance of power armor has markedly declined from previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre; everything about this game is middling except for the fact that it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. It's significantly more stable in comparison to Fallout 3. Is it superior to Fallout 3? No. Is it superior to New Vegas? No. This title was excessively hyped, inconsistent with its actual quality.

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :D This puzzle-platforming game features a diminutive protagonist donning a fez, who traverses the game collecting fragments to form a cube while navigating a vast, branching map. The game is quite entertaining, and completing it was a delightful experience. ^_^ However, it can become somewhat frustrating if one aims to collect all the cubes and achievements. To obtain every cube, players must solve codes that require deciphering. These puzzles may take a mere few seconds or may provoke frustration to the point of consulting a guide (*raises hand* I succumbed. -_-). The guide, titled 'A Complete Guide to Fez!!!',

It's not difficult for me to understand why other people enjoy this game, but it wasn't to my liking. For one thing, I have a Vive and I'm much more intrigued by playing room-sized games with the controllers. Furthermore, the game is initially awe-inspiring in the scope of its universe, but I also felt that same enormity was a hindrance to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the duration required to engage in anything captivating at the outset were both too steep for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had ample time for gaming, this would be appealing to me. However, I lack both patience and time, and there are numerous other VR games I would prefer to invest my time in.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun Rambo's need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in lethal outcomes unless the bullet merely grazes you. Rounds descend over distance and short, controlled bursts are necessary if you wish to maintain accuracy. There is no infinite ammunition reserve. Continually reloading mid-magazine means you will end up with a collection of partially filled mags. Your stamina is not endless. If you sprint for an extended period, your marksmanship will deteriorate as you pant heavily until you regain your breath. Support your weapon on your elbows while prone, or on a windowsill, to stabilize your aim. Precision diminishes when standing.

Let me start off by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out and that I acquired it on sale, which included EW, so I never encountered the problems that some individuals allege to have experienced with that game. I adored that game; however, it was unforgiving in the initial stages, yet rewarding when you executed strategies correctly. As for XCOM 2, I love it. The game performs quite well for me on medium settings, and I am running a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game set the graphics to high, and it ran somewhat sluggishly - not to the point of being unplayable, but when I lowered it to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not certain if I am simply fortunate regarding issues with games or what, but it seems that most of the negative reviews appear to stem from rather entitled individuals.
